text: Of fowls after their kind, and of cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the earth after his kind, two of every sort shall come unto thee, to keep them alive.
text_kjv: Of fowls after their kind, and of cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the earth after his kind, two of every sort shall come unto thee, to keep them alive.
text_niv: Two of every kind of bird, of every kind of animal and of every kind of creature that moves along the ground will come to you to be kept alive.
text_esv: Of the birds according to their kinds, and of the animals according to their kinds, of every creeping thing of the ground, according to its kind, two of every sort shall come in to you to keep them alive.
text_nlt: Pairs of every kind of bird, and every kind of animal, and every kind of small animal that scurries along the ground, will come to you to be kept alive.
text_msg: two of every species of bird, mammal, and reptile—two of everything so as to preserve their lives along with yours.
text_nasb: 'Of the birds after their kind, and of the animals after their kind, of every creeping thing of the ground after its kind, two of every [kind] will come to you to keep [them] alive.
context:
Genesis 6:20 is nestled deep within one of the most pivotal and dramatic narratives in the Bible: the account of Noah and the Great Flood. To understand this specific verse, we must first grasp the bleak backdrop against which God's command to Noah was given. The book of Genesis, traditionally attributed to Moses, was likely written for the Israelites as they journeyed through the wilderness, providing them with foundational truths about their origins, God's character, and His covenant relationship with humanity.

The chapters leading up to Genesis 6 depict a world that had spiraled into profound moral decay. Genesis 6:5 starkly states, “The Lord saw that the wickedness of humankind was great in the earth, and that every inclination of the thoughts of their hearts was only evil continually.” This was not merely isolated acts of sin, but a pervasive, systemic corruption that saturated human existence. Violence, injustice, and a complete disregard for God’s design had become the norm. God, described as being grieved to His heart, made the drastic decision to cleanse the earth through a flood, effectively 'blotting out' the corrupted human and animal life He had created.

However, amidst this overwhelming darkness, one man found favor in the eyes of the Lord: Noah (Genesis 6:8). Noah was described as a righteous man, blameless in his generation, and he walked faithfully with God (Genesis 6:9). It is to this man that God reveals His plan of judgment and, crucially, His plan of salvation and preservation. Genesis 6 details God's meticulous instructions to Noah for building the ark – a vessel designed to save a remnant of humanity and every kind of land-dwelling creature. Verse 20, therefore, is a direct, divine command within this larger instruction set, highlighting God's commitment not only to human redemption but also to the preservation of His broader creation. It underscores God's sovereignty over nature, His justice in judging sin, and His profound mercy in providing a way forward for life to continue on earth.
meaning:
Genesis 6:20 delivers a crucial directive within God's grand plan of preservation, rich with theological truths. Let's break it down phrase by phrase:

"Of fowls after their kind, and of cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the earth after his kind": The repeated phrase "after their kind" (לְמִינָהּ, *lᵉmînâhh*) is incredibly significant. It echoes Genesis 1, where God created all living things "after their kind," establishing distinct biological categories. This wasn't merely a descriptive observation; it signified fixed reproductive boundaries, ensuring that birds produce birds, cattle produce cattle, and so on. In the context of the flood, it reassures Noah (and us) that the diverse forms of life God created would be preserved in their original, distinct biological identities. There would be no blurring of species; God's original creative order, even amidst judgment, would be maintained. This highlights God's design, order, and faithfulness to His creation principles.

"two of every sort shall come unto thee": This is a powerful statement of divine sovereignty and miraculous intervention. Noah wasn't tasked with hunting down or capturing all these diverse creatures. The Hebrew word for "come" (בּוֹא, *bo'*) here implies a directed movement towards a specific point. God explicitly promises that the animals *will come* to Noah. This eliminates any doubt about how Noah, a human, could possibly gather such a vast array of creatures. It underscores that this massive undertaking was not dependent on Noah's strength or ingenuity, but entirely on God's miraculous orchestration and power over His creation. While later in Genesis 7:2-3, God clarifies that seven pairs of clean animals and birds would come, this initial command establishes the general principle of preserving life in pairs, male and female, necessary for procreation post-flood.

"to keep them alive": This phrase reveals the ultimate purpose behind God's command. The flood was an act of righteous judgment, wiping out a world steeped in sin. Yet, God's intention was not total annihilation, but preservation. Life, in all its forms, holds value in God's eyes. This act of preservation is a profound demonstration of God's mercy and His commitment to the continuity of His creation. It shows that even in the midst of divine wrath, God's character is interwoven with grace and the desire for new beginnings. This isn't just about human survival; it's about God's plan for the entire created order to endure and flourish again.

Theologically, this verse teaches us about God's absolute sovereignty over all creation, His meticulous planning, His balance of justice and mercy, and the inherent value He places on life. It fits into the broader biblical narrative by setting the stage for the repopulation of the earth and establishing the Noahic covenant, which explicitly includes all living creatures (Genesis 9:9-10). It also foreshadows God's consistent character throughout Scripture: a God who judges sin but always provides a way for salvation and renewal.
application:
Genesis 6:20, though describing an ancient event, resonates deeply with timeless truths that offer powerful applications for modern life. It speaks to God's providence, our stewardship, and the nature of His character.

**1. Trusting God's Supernatural Provision in Impossible Situations:** Noah was given a task of unprecedented scale: build a massive ark and then, according to this verse, receive representatives of every land-dwelling animal 'kind.' The critical detail is that the animals "will come unto thee." Noah didn't have to hunt or capture them; God promised to orchestrate their arrival. This teaches us profound lessons about God's supernatural provision.

*   **Real-life scenario:** Imagine you are facing a seemingly insurmountable personal challenge – perhaps a dire financial crisis, a chronic health issue with no clear cure, or a relational breakdown that feels irreparable. You've exhausted all your human resources, and the weight of the situation is crushing.
*   **Application:** In these moments, we are called to move beyond human capability and trust in divine intervention. Like Noah, we must be obedient to what God *has* called us to do (e.g., pray, seek wise counsel, work diligently, practice forgiveness), even when the 'how' of the larger solution is unclear. Then, we rest in the promise that God will orchestrate the impossible. He can move mountains, change hearts, or provide resources in ways we could never anticipate. This isn't passive waiting; it's active obedience coupled with profound trust that God will bring what is needed – the 'animals' for our 'ark' – in His perfect timing and miraculous way. It reminds us that our limitations are merely opportunities for God's limitless power to be displayed.

**2. Embracing Our Role as Stewards of God's Diverse Creation:** The command "to keep them alive" for every "kind" highlights God's intrinsic value for all life and His delegation of stewardship to humanity. Noah's ark was a testament to God's desire for the preservation of His created order.

*   **Real-life scenario:** Our modern world faces unprecedented environmental challenges: climate change, species extinction, pollution of air and water, and deforestation. It's easy to feel overwhelmed or disconnected from these global issues.
*   **Application:** Genesis 6:20 calls us to action. If God cared enough to save representatives of every animal 'kind,' how much more should we, as His image-bearers, care for the planet He entrusted to us? This means making conscious choices in our daily lives: reducing our consumption, recycling, supporting sustainable practices, advocating for environmental protection, and educating ourselves and others about the health of our planet. It’s about recognizing that our consumption habits, waste production, and political choices have real impacts on God's precious creation. Our stewardship extends beyond our immediate needs to the well-being of the diverse ecosystem God created, ensuring that future generations can also experience its wonder.

**3. Finding Unity and Value Amidst God's Diversity:** The repeated phrase "after their kind" emphasizes distinctiveness, yet God brought *all* these diverse 'kinds' together into one ark for preservation. This is a powerful metaphor for human diversity and unity.

*   **Real-life scenario:** In our increasingly polarized world, we often see divisions along racial, cultural, political, or socio-economic lines. Churches, workplaces, and communities can struggle to foster genuine unity when differences are perceived as threats rather than strengths.
*   **Application:** Just as God saw value in preserving every distinct animal 'kind' in the ark, He values the incredible diversity within humanity. We are all made in His image, yet we come from different backgrounds, possess unique gifts, and hold varied perspectives. This verse encourages us to move beyond tribalism and appreciate the richness that diversity brings. It calls us to cultivate environments—whether in our families, churches, or communities—where different 'kinds' of people can coexist, learn from each other, and contribute to a common purpose. True unity isn't uniformity, but a beautiful mosaic where distinct parts are brought together by God's design and purpose, all working 'to keep them alive' – preserving relationships, fostering understanding, and promoting flourishing for all.
prayer:
Oh, Lord God,

What an incredible and awe-inspiring picture this verse paints! You, the Creator of all, orchestrating the very animals to come to Noah, not just to save humanity, but to keep alive every 'kind' you made. It reminds me, Father, of your immense power and your meticulous care for all creation. Your hand moved not just the waves, but also the hearts and instincts of every creature, guiding them to safety.

Lord, so often I face situations that feel utterly overwhelming, tasks that seem impossible for me to accomplish, or futures that appear uncertain. Just like Noah, who couldn't possibly have gathered all those animals himself, I often feel my own limitations. Help me to remember this promise: 'they will come unto thee.' Help me to trust that when you give a command, you also provide the means, and often, you orchestrate the impossible. Strengthen my faith to step out in obedience, knowing that you will fill in the gaps that are beyond my ability.

Thank you for your mercy, God, that even in judgment, you provide a way for life and new beginnings. Inspire me to be a better steward of the creation you’ve entrusted to me, to value the diversity of life, and to play my part in preserving the beauty and order you designed. May I also extend that same spirit of preservation and grace to the people around me, appreciating their unique 'kinds' and contributing to their flourishing. Strengthen my faith to believe you are sovereign over every detail, and that your plans for preservation and life will always prevail. Amen.

faqs.answer: The biblical text specifically mentions "fowls," "cattle," and "creeping things of the earth" (Genesis 6:20), indicating land-dwelling, air-breathing animals. Marine life (fish, whales, etc.) would not have needed to be on the ark as they live in water, which was the medium of judgment. Insects are often thought to have been preserved in various forms or were not explicitly mentioned as needing to be 'kept alive' in the same manner as larger vertebrates. Plants could survive as seeds or root systems. Dinosaurs, if coexisting with humans, would have likely been included as juveniles or eggs, or perhaps the 'kinds' represented were smaller, more manageable forms of what we now classify as dinosaurs. The focus was on preserving a remnant of terrestrial vertebrate life that would perish in the floodwaters.
faqs.question: Was it really *all* the animals? What about fish, insects, plants, or dinosaurs?

faqs.answer: Noah's role wasn't primarily about 'collecting' the animals, but about obeying God's instruction to *prepare* the ark. The animals 'came' to him, demonstrating God's supernatural provision. In modern challenges, this means we are called to obey God's commands and do our part (e.g., diligent work, prayer, seeking wise counsel), but we must also trust God for the seemingly impossible elements beyond our control. When you feel overwhelmed by a task, remember that God orchestrates His plan, often providing what you cannot. Your obedience, even in the smallest steps, opens the door for His miraculous provision to manifest in your life, bringing the 'animals' you need to your 'ark'.
faqs.question: How can I apply Noah's faith in collecting animals to my modern challenges and seemingly impossible tasks?

faqs.answer: The phrase "after their kind" (לְמִינָהּ, *lᵉmînâhh*) is crucial, echoing Genesis 1. It emphasizes God's original design for distinct, reproducing biological categories or 'kinds.' In the context of the flood, its repetition assures Noah and the readers that the preserved animals would maintain their unique identities and reproductive capabilities, ensuring the continuation of the specific diverse life forms God created. It speaks against arbitrary blending or the loss of species, highlighting divine order and biological stability in the face of global catastrophe. It underscores God's faithfulness to His initial creation principles even as He judges the earth.
faqs.question: Why is 'after their kind' repeated so many times in this verse and throughout Genesis?

faqs.answer: Genesis 6:20 gives the initial, general command for 'two of every sort' (a pair for preservation and reproduction). Genesis 7:2-3 provides a more specific, additional instruction just before the flood, clarifying that *seven* pairs of clean animals and birds were to be brought, while only one pair of unclean animals. The purpose for the additional clean animals was twofold: for sacrifice after the flood (Genesis 8:20) as an act of worship and gratitude to God, and for food (Genesis 9:3) as humanity's diet was expanded after the flood, indicating God's foresight for both spiritual and physical sustenance in the post-flood world.
faqs.question: How does Genesis 6:20, stating 'two of every sort,' relate to the later instruction about seven pairs of clean animals in Genesis 7:2-3?

faqs.answer: Absolutely. The command "to keep them alive" (לְהַחֲיוֹת, *lᵉhaḥăyôt*) reveals God's deep concern for the preservation of all His creation. Noah was entrusted with the stewardship of animal life, not just for human benefit, but because God values every 'kind.' This foundational principle translates directly to modern environmentalism and animal welfare. We, too, are stewards of God's earth and its diverse creatures. This verse underscores our responsibility to care for the planet, protect endangered species, and live sustainably and ethically, reflecting God's own value for creation and His desire for its flourishing rather than its destruction or exploitation.
